bow: have second child and become sahm or keep my job my husband and have two and half year old son that we adore he is wonderful boy have started thinking about having second child my husband said he retirement would take if did that we could afford childcare for two children but it would be really tight the biggest reason he said that is that when our son was born worked 3pm to 11pm so he had the baby almost every evening by himself and that was really hard time for him but when was home it was lot easier for him so he told me he is fine with having second child as long as am home what would you guys do it seems like he saying that he happy to have second if it doesn inconvenience him too much that doesn seem like great dynamic to start out with sahp and really like it but it isn for everyone and we have built my time out of the work force into our retirement planning it seems like you need to have some more discussions could you get different job with different schedule could you shift to part time and share that burden little more evenly is he ok contributing extra to retirement to compensate for you not doing so and is that something your budget allows if you decide to stay home how long does he expect that of you how long are you ok doing so what do you want that really the only question to answer here personally am terrible sahm love my children but being with them 24 become lazy mom and resentful of my lack of free time and personal space also then become resentful of my husband freedom my mental health is better when have my own career spent long time getting into the career wanted lots of education and grunt work job and did so because love it and because it also allows me flexible work schedule so handle pick up and drop off at daycare doctors appt school volunteering etc also my work allows me to bring my kids with me if someone is sick or we have snow day realize that not normal and extremely flexible took my second into work with me every day for the first six months but give that example because you ve got time to change your work to somewhere else that allows you that flexibility and it will make having second child much easier also look at other daycare options we loved our original place and it had high price tag we started looking elsewhere when our oldest was getting older and found an even better daycare that was less expensive really think through all your options and what will make you happy love being sahm and do have any regrets about that decision understand that it not for everyone but you said you did have any issues with it so why not try it and see if it what best for your family so he fine with second kid if it does alter his life too much that how read this anyway keep in mind that there lot to consider here not just your retirement savings but also future earning potential have several friends men and women both who have left the workforce to be stay at home parents the problem they have all run into is that with many fields it pretty hard to return once you ve been out of the workforce for several years from what ve seen they have all struggled to re enter the workforce and then once they did their earning potential was way down also consider whether you really want to stay at home some people love it some people do carefully consider whether this is something you can mentally tolerate it not for everyone removed have the kid stay home for awhile you may love it or you may not and then you can figure something else out you never know what going to happen 40 years down the road so hate to miss out on something as meaningful as having another child giving your son sibling just for the sake of the retirement fund you can also consider part time daycare options like monday wednesday friday or tuesday thursday or just mornings or afternoons this reduces the cost and gives balance so you get break and spend more time with your children maybe try watching someones kid along with chance of finding freelance consulting work from home in your field especially since you love your work but hate the company have always been sahm who works from home and it is nice to have some contact with the adult world during the day as well as making it easier to re enter the job market down the road would personally say no because it sounds like your partner doesn want to coparent anywhere close to equally and you ll be stay at home servant not mom if he is willing to maintain 50 of the house chores and be in charge when he home then maybe but it sounds like you ll have new baby and husband will have lots of free time away from the pesky kids your older child will be in preschool before baby is born that will give you both bit more free time sounds like you should keep your job to be sahm or not is very personal decision have been on both sides went back to work after my months of maternity leave was actually happy and excited to be back but had never particularly liked the job had at the time and then it started to get really awful and was working late all the time finally caved in and talked to my husband crying and begging for him to be ok with me quitting have been sahm for 10 months now and am crawling out of my skin really want to go back to work but this time need less demanding job that don hate however it will be while before can go back because am now pregnant with our second guess the takeaway here is that if you have job you love you may want to seriously consider keeping it though some love it for me being sahm has made me feel isolated kids are in highschool give serious thought to whether or not it be feasible to do your work part time am freelancer my work ca be done from home but pick my assignments and how many hours work since becoming mom work part time about 10 hours week during the school year and take off the entire summer and school holidays this has enabled me to not miss out on anything with my kids but also enjoy time away from them and no detriment to my career have made enough sahm and teacher friends that we have wonderful social network to hang out with when home with my kids in fact we re usually just home for meals and naps do do well with physically being home all day is your career flexible in that you can jump back in after taking say five year break because you could choose to be sahm until both your children are in school and then get back to your career there are so many variables and there isn one size fits all answer it really depends on you your family and your industry in some industries you can break back in or even work from home with the right job in others this simply isn possible how is it in your industry also how ambitious are you and is it possible to rise while this job something that pays high enough to justify childcare expenses do you mind outsourcing or would you rather be around all day can you guys swing it on one income these are all things to think
